editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

keywords.term: Suffolk, Katharine Willoughby Brandon, -- Duchess of, -- 1519-1580 -- Drama -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: The life of the Duchess of Suffolk ▪
As it hath been divers and sundry times acted, with good applause.
Imprinted by A. m. for Jasper Emery; at flowerdeluce in Paul's churchyard. 1631.

div.head: Actus primus.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Knights, gentlemen, and yeomen,
Attend her grace's service; she'll abroad.

div.stage: Enter Cranwell ushering the Duchess of Suffolk, a gentlewoman bearing up her train, Bertie, and gentlemen. 〈…〉 at the other door Begger

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Be uncovered gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Rome there, back beggars.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Bertie, deal mine alms.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Pray for the Duchess, friends.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Heavens preserve your grace.

div.stage: Enter one with a letter, delivers it kneeling.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What sayest thou? from my King? I kiss his lips
As humbly as my infant penitence,
When due correction threatened mine offence:
I may entreat the Palatine with grace,
All courtesy and favours, for my sovereign's sake,
I will present him with smooth countenance,
But for the point here touching marriage,
Beseech my prince of pardon, since, as yet,
My widow's tears are scarce wiped from my cheek,
Touching the business, about sir Roger Willoughby,
My dear near kinsman, I'll not return
You empty handed back, but send
His highness Parram lordship to dispose,
And thank his gracious providence for him.
Return my salutations on my knee,
And say my whole possessions are all his,
Berty reward his pains, on;
sp.stage: Enter Gardner to the tower guarded.
sp.l: Stay, and know the reason of that guard,
How? give mine eyes the fullness of their wish,
Screen not my joys, I pray stand all aside,
My gossip Gardner led unto the tower,
'Tis pity, nay man leave your courtesy,
My passion has no tears to answer you,
Truth now I hope hath got a holiday,
The tyrant wolf in hold, the lambs may play,
Forward to Sussex house in Barnisby street:
More objects yet of comfort? what is he?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Bonner commanded to the martial fie.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Faggots will then grow cheap, they say, my lord,
That you have bought up all our firewood,
To send us in a shining flame to heaven,
But Bertie, see how lean has study made him,
And his care with sweating in repress of errors,
An ell will hardly girdle his lean waist.
Sands, I'll defer your welcome yet from Cambridge,
To show you here a precedent of zeal.

sp.speaker: Bonn ▪
sp.l: Madam these scorns live not with charity,
My conscience is content to bear this cross.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And mine as well content that thou shouldst bear it,
Think'st thou I will disburden thy content,
good man thou art deceived, my charity
Shuts up the doors against thy misery,
I tell thee, all my sorrows are dried up,
With this sweet breath of comfort, to see thee,
Infranchise truth by thy captivity.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Time flatters you awhile, heaven has a power,
Can change the white to sable in an hour,
My wealthier thoughts, yet tell me I shall live,
These scorns to quittance, your free heart to grieve,
For time is rich in ransom, she may raise,
The scorned and captived Bonner, beware those days.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: If England's sin deserves that curse again,
Doubtless my life the truth should still maintain.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.l: The grace of heaven make strong that your resolve

sp.speaker: Duchess ▪
sp.l: Tut sands, I am no novice to bear off
The gusty shock of danger, here is proof,
Hath bid the cannon of rough threatening grief,
The deaths of one dear husband, and two sons,
(Regenerate in the fame of their deserts.)
Have made a violent shot against this breast,
But by the manly courage of that joy,
Is knit unto my spirits, to behold
The exild truth, now sojourning with time,
The rage of their repugnancy recoils,
And I am mistress of a virgin heart.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: With pardon gracious madam,
Could Bertie's rude persuasion please your ears,
I wish it clothed with Hymen's royalties:
A husband, like an ammell, would enrich
Your golden virtues.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How men can praise themselves.
Marriage is good, but where's the husband good?
A loving husband, Bertie, true in touch
May swear, so they will be, few prove such.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Dared my opinion venture, but to speak him,
I could commend that merit to your heart,
As I presume, your fancy would embrace.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Void all the chamber, Bertie, but yourself,
The husband now, come man, fear not to speak,
You have absolution, ere you do begin,
The husband can report his true deserts.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: As much as observations greedy eye,
Could well retain, keeps warm upon my tongue,
Which to your noblest consideration was in honour's womb,
And from her sucked his nutriment of life,
His spirit like an ensign doth display
The worthiness of his heroic birth,
His more concealed virtues varnish that,
To make his comet (Merit,) wondered at,
Nature in moulding of his lineaments,
Has shamed the cunning workmanship of art,
That he is madam, as your wish would make,
The richer in desert for your worths sake.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You have described the substance of a man,
Such as might ravish the most chastest thoughts,
Virginity could sin in wish of him,
For but on my deceased Brandon's breath,
Did never wait such rich perfections,
In them I shall but re-espouse mine own,
Marry one husband twice, embrace the dead,
Hug in mine arms a Suffolk buried ▪

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: If honourable love live in a man,
It guides the virtues of the Palatine.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The Palatine? has he your wishes voice.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Could it assure him of your fancy's choice.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: His stately honours are unmatched for mine.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: His greatness reflects beams into your shine.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That greatness claims a duty from my heart.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No more than his love offers your desert.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Your humble eyes see's merit, his will not,
Our weaker worths in marriage are forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Nay rather madam wedlock doth enroll,
The special essence of your rare deserts,
remembering your perfections.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ay, they could live in your humility,
And my affections best afford them thee,
Whilst thy sweet tongue solicits for thy friend,
Into thy bosom all my thoughts I send.
Cranwell what news.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: The county palatine, now King of Poland.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: King of Poland?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Madam survey your thoughts,
Master your fears, and crown your happiness,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: King of Poland?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You Queen my hopes would see.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Queen of my rich desires in marrying thee ▪
What of this King of Poland?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: He stays your grace's leisure,
Accompanied with the Earl of Arundel.

div.stage: Enter the Palatine being King of Poland, and Arundell.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Entreat their presence,
Welcome royal prince,
My noble lord.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Madam, my latest service comes to bring
An old affection from a new made King.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My pristine gratulations thus accept
The humble proffer of your sovereign heart ▪
But let me tell you, my thrice gracious lord,
You deal not kingly, by advantaged means
To set upon my infancy of love,
To ambush lay it by intelligence:
You know my meaning, there's a privy thief
I know you set to pillage my affections,
He durst not else have broke my secrets up.
His travel has not loitered in your suit,
Nor will I be ungrateful to his pains.
The Duke Northumberland, with the Earl of Erbaigh,
Desire to have access unto your grace.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: More suitors? well, they are all welcome; usher them in.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Health and fair fortune
Wait on suffolk's Duchess.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Your wishes return their virtues on yourself.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: The King salutes you in my vassal breath,
And bade me tell you, he received your gift
With thankful welcome, and bestowed the same ▪
(Pieced out with honour, from his noble bounty)
Upon your cousin sir Roger Willowby,
Creating him lord Willowby of Parram,
To build remembrance of your gracious gift:
Further he prays you to entreat this prince,
The Earl of Erbaigh with fair courtesy.

sp.speaker: Erba.
sp.l: Madam, the love of your perfections ▪
Hath called me hither, and of them I crave,
A welcome to my loyalty of heart.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I wish sir, my perfections of that wealth
To rate so high a merit as yours is:
But princes, leave this cheapening of my love,
It is a bad thing dear.
Shall I beseech of you my lord of Poland, and the rest,
Princes or whosoever tenders me
The humble service of his noble heart
As to digest my choice with patience:
Amongst you I will choose, and at this time
And in his like inter my widowhood,
Amongst a throng of merits one but enters,
One wins the goal still ▪ though a thousand venters,
This man must but possess me, let the voice
of my affections, please all with her choice.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: Pleased or displeased, you women choose you● kiss
And reason you should have it, or all's one
You'll take a fall to have it; fancies force
Makes honest plainness often speed the worse,
Choose madam choose, and please thine own content

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: The King of Poland madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How this fellow
Wakes my remembrance for the King of Poland,
As though my fancy hung upon his tongue,
I never shot a blunted arrow forth,
Nor shall my choice recoil upon his worth,
Whom I'll call mine; come worst of fate,
Berty I choose thyself my marriage mate,
Upon this low foundation I erect
The palace of mine honours, on this knee
I place the head of mine authority;
Let hand from hand exchange their offices,
What's mine is thine, thine mine, sealed with this kiss.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: How madcap Duchess; what and join lips
Whate'er we thought, I see it is a match.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You see blind fancies folly in my choice,
His worth prevails, nor will I change my voice.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: By the dear loyalty my thoughts do owe
To this unmeasured grace you heap on me,
And by the virtue of a Christian faith,
The relish of this blessing is so strong,
That when I leave to love, I live too long.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Princes, let your displeasure chide his merit
Which stole my love your honours would inherit.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: My fury thus bursts forth, to wish increase
Of your spouse virtues in your lives sweet peace.

sp.speaker: Erba.
sp.l: My hatred dies not so, but I would see
Your merits live in your posterity.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Whereat frown you sir?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I hope it is no breach of duty, to conceal
Our close affections, they are privileged,
and I will keep them so, you have my service;
If it may pleasure, so; if not, I care not:
I'll mourn mine own sins,
Take your cloak and spare not.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: If you be tired with the wearing it,
Good speed you, I'll not break you back with care.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: You have my heart, whilst I an honest ass,
(For so I count all men of patience,)
Have laden it with whole loads of businesses ▪
With jaunting on your errands, drudged at home,
With so strong diligence, that sleep could scarce
Approach my eyelids for a se'ennight's space:
The honour of your cellar lives in me,
You scarce command a throat can gulp a health,
You think I flatter, take good fellows words,
And him whose merit claims pre-eminence,
By their opinion, deal your recompense.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: If you mean me, I will not canvas
With you for the voice of quaint opinion;
You'll way down the scales,
Her honourable love, the gift of fate,
Not due of merit, doth advance my state.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Why sir, might she not bestow her love on me?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: She might.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: She might, more fool she did not, but all's one
All friends now, here's my hand, my spleens down.

sp.speaker: Bert,
sp.l: In this embrace I send a general love,
To all my fellow servitors:
I know some lours upon my happiness,
How undeserved, let my offices
Of love to you, and duty to her grace,
In their impartial verdict render up.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: O, take my answer as the general voice,
For from my mouth breathes their opinions:
She lessens not her honours in your choice,
But makes you lord of her affections,
And them we serve not, but her royalties,
which, as they are not lessened, why should we
Shrink from their service; whom her love doth honour
May challenge from us special reverence,
And so shall you, as homage for that love,
Whose sovereignty commands our services.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Consent I see is liberal to this match,
And offers frankly my applauding heart,
Wishing of heaven to smile upon your loves,
That from them may grow up such gallant spirits
As may renown this land with honoured merits.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Good morrow to my lord of Winchester ▪
How do you like our air i'th Marshalseas,
From that ith' tower? welcome to't my lord.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: O I thank your love,
But had we once our liberties,
We would set night upon these morning skies.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O that that hour were come, the King on●

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: What's that my lord of London?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Ay, pray man, pray, that heaven would take
Our good King Edward to yond happy land,
He's sick, he's sick, heaven take the infant child ▪
For this cracked world his virtues are too mild:
Is not this charitable, what sayst thou man?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: But is the King sick?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And princes Mary well,
O how I long to hear his passing bell.
Soft who comes here.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Health to my honoured lords.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: That were, thou meanest.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: That are, I bring your lordships from our an 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Queen? is Edward dead?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: King Edward, of that name the sixth, is dead, and

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Who, who I beseech thee, guides the state?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: She that repeals you to your former seats,
Royal Queen Mary.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: See.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Good hold my back, this sudden blast of comfort
Blows me up, where is my rival Ridley and the rest,
They now shall fire for this.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Sent down to Oxford.

sp.speaker: Gard ▪
sp.l: Thence they shall not stir,
Till fire consume them, if I be Winchester.

sp.speaker: Clu ▪
sp.l: By me her highness greets you with that sea,
Adding unto it, high chancellor of England.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: An office good my lord may coin revenge
With justice' stamp to pay our enemies.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My lord of London, that's your title now,
Restored unto it with her grace's favour.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And if affection lenify my duty ▪
Let me respectless die without her favour.

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Where be the lords of Winchester and London?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The good lord Paget, welcome, pray, what news sir?

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Her highness gives us joint commission
By virtue of this patent to peruse,
And cleanse the state of impious sectaries,
Wherewith it was infected in the days
Of her deceased brother Edward's reign,

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Without affection of affinity.

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Of any, not her sister is except.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Then let our Suffolk's dowager expect
Answer for her scorned taunts, she threw on me of late
That hot spirit, fire and flax, madam faggot stick,
If she recant not I will faggot her,
If all the wood in Middlesex can doo●,
Or London's bishopric have means to pay fort
I'll not niggard her bones and I do, arraign my charity

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: I have already sent process for her husband
Forth by Cluny.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My man, a trusty fellow
Worthy employment in the Lollards tower,
But here comes Bartie, welcome honest Cluny
It was well done, an honest knave, I'll gratify thy love▪
As I will quittance such malignant hates.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As whose, an't please your lordship.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: A vengeance flatter you,
Your courteous ear, wears daggers in your heart.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My ear, my lord, is servant to my heart.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: They serve indeed to guide the envious heart.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Sure I think Bertie be an honest man,
Religious was his education,
With our deceased chancellor whom he served,
If since his lady have not weaned him from it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Your honour still shall find me the same man.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: In substance, but how in religion?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As than a member of the self same church.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My good lady your wife sir, she's not so.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I do beseech your lordships to suspend
And smother your opinions till a trial
Blow up the embers to an open flame,
Then censure as you find, and give's your doom.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: If we but find her answers half so calm.

sp.speaker: Bon ▪
sp.l: Yes as thunder, she calm? as a baited bear,
I will oppose my disputation,
Against a college of best discipline,
Rather than with her brains, she sticks her jests ▪
Like poisoned arrows, in our tender spleens:
Thinking the sanctuary of her high birth ▪
To privilege her fond presumption,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My credit sir be pawned.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your credit tut tut, she hangs upon the mercy of the Queen,
But it will cast off her opinion.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Should she be cold, my lords, or set a frown
Upon the alteration of her faith,
Your lordships know the sums of money due,
From Charles the emperor to her in the right,
Of her departed husband, Suffolk's Duke,
Which if your honourable licence would
Assign me a free passage to those parts
To gather up your unexpected love,
Would heat her good opinion with the zeal.
Where now the strangeness makes her somewhat stagger.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Let him go my lords, you shall go speed him hence
The way is broader unto our revenge,
Which I have sworn to take upon that dame,
Whose scornful taunts did so deprave my fame.
What says my good chancellor to this suit.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: You have free passage Bertie, when you please.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: To scape your envies, if we cross the seas.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Follow him Cluny and when thou thinkest,
The solemn farewell of divorced lips,
Hath part this husband from his honoured wife,
With some especial servants of the Queen
Enter the Duchess house in Barbican,
Take a true inventory of all her goods,
Discharge her household, save a man or two.
One woman, and the nurse that suckles her child,
And say you have commandment from the Queen
To stay there till her highness' further pleasure,
That she shall walk the highway to the tower,
Be gone, perform thine office carefully,
And I will pay thy pains as liberally.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: I go my lord, but do you hear the news?
How doctor sands is scaped from the King's bench, and fled.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Send forth our warrants into every coast.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Towards Kent ▪ towards Kent, post Cluny, run villain
How starest thou? pack.
Live in my bosom if thou bring him back,
This sands is chaplain to yond scornful Duchess,
And he has ta'ne this lesson from her brains,
That house of sly devises, she's all wit,
Nor shall I sleep until I ruin it.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: Madam, my promise of your penitence,
Weighed with the puissance of your high birth,
Wherein you are allied unto the Queen,
Calmed the rough menace of stout Gardner,
And set a reverence on stern bonners tongue,
Humbly to wish your reformation.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The Queen is near and dear unto my blood
In the remembrance of our mother's loves,
Which chargeth greater sorrow at my heart,
Than the huge shock of their malignant threats;
My soul hath lodged the truth, it shall not thence,
Whilst this weak flesh displays her airy sense.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But madam, let your wisdom shut her up,
Commit her not unto your state to guard,
But humble your high spirit, sleike your speech,
That envy may not stumble at mistrust,
Or find a rub to start suspicion:
Wear a smooth brow in presence of your foes,
Be shaken with their threats, retreat your spirit,
Till they insult upon your patience:
The conquest won in your submission,
They slake the eager pursuit of revenge,
To give you time to purvey for your scape;
You know my leave of passage o'er the seas,
and with what cunning I have coloured it,
To free my conscience from the gale of fear.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But still leave mine upon the rock of care.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I go to seek releasement of that care,
Freely to spread the ensign of your faith:
A simple, rustic home of liberty,
Is worth your honours in captivity.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: It is, it is, and would befit our hues,
To wear them out in contemplation:
There should we read, upon the naked walls,
The first creation of our wretchedness;
There no intruding objects of gay clothes,
Embroidered hangings, or rich tapestry,
Shall wound the service which we owe to heaven.
O m. Bertie, there my wish would be;
Change honoured woe for poor felicity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I'll lay a bark at Leigh shall stay for you,
To be transported to me at Midelborow.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But who conducts me to that bark at Leigh?
Fear is a trusty guide, it is, it is,
She that knows no way, that way will not miss,
I prithee go, my conscience to set free,
My tender feet shall learn to follow thee.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yet stay, nay go, alas which way?
And must we part?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: We must,
My body's here, thou hast my heart along with thee
Make much on't prithee, till we meet again,
My body and my soul you both retain.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Slip not my duty, I beseech your love,
To her for whom my sorrows shed more tears ▪
Then is my wounded conscience charged with fears.

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: Patience, good madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Passion master Bertie,
My spleen is wounded with compassionate pity,
I could drop out my liver, ●ob my life
of her dear essence, with immoderate sighs,
For that sweet princes, wronged Elizabeth ▪
Now in the gripe of their pernicious hate,
A guard of angels ring her life about,
From the malicious practice of her foes;
Rebate their furies, cross their treacherous ways,
Let truth in her outlive these bloody days.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Amen, amen, what shall I deliver to her from 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A comfortable salutation
To that heart sorrowing lady which my prayer
From heaven has carried to her heart before.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Will you ought else?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A kind embrace from you, exchange a tear, 〈◊〉
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O this doth clog me more, ways down my spirit
Should bear our fortunes to a soft repose,
Not daring here to peep out of our thoughts,
Without the danger of the vulture's gripe,
Whose watching eyes of inquisition
Steals covertly upon our purposes,
And yet you lag me with your load of griefs.
I could toss woe for woe until tomorrow,
But then weed wake the wolf with bleating sorrow.
With what unwillingness I part from you
Let that and these received.
Adieu, adieu.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Now Cranwell, what wouldst thou? thy m. go●

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: I am glad he stayed not, to piece out our money

sp.speaker: Duke ▪
sp.l: What heavy think strains moisture from thy heart

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: To see your greatness struck with envy's da●●
Her highness' servants have attached your goods,
Discharging all your household officers.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What remedy? this was my expectation: I was away
with complete resolution, to abide
The rigorous wrestle of this stream-born tide.
Faintest thou at this? than thou wouldst swoon to see
My honoured state changed to ragged misery.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: I will not line to see that.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Then thy love is tried:
I thought it would have lackeyed by my side.

sp.speaker: Cran ▪
sp.l: How mean you madam?
When it tires in service of your grace,
May I never more have being on the earth,
Were you to pass th'extremest of all woe,
Might I be worthy, I would share with you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Upon thy trust, than I repose my life,
Provide me 'gainst this even a citizen's gown,
Ath' meanest fashion, like my present fortunes:
This night I'll hazard to escape from hence,
Putting my fears into the hand of fate,
To trample on or readvance my state,
Wilt thou about it?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: With a winged speed:
To cure your sorrows this manly heart shall bleed.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Madam this world is changed.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Change thou with it.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Change, and I did it were no heresy:
These humours grapple with my honesty,
But they are frantic fits, I let them pass.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sir what are you?

sp.speaker: C●u:
sp.l: My name is Cluny, and now your grace's keeper.

sp.speaker: Duchess ▪
sp.l: I hear you have discharged my household servants.

sp.speaker: Clu:
sp.l: It is her highness' pleasure.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Or Bonners hate, but I accept it with a thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Clu:
sp.l: All are not yet discharged, but your choice
May call two men, a woman, and a nurse.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Nay, Cranwell is all I will beseech of you.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Why Cranwell, more than fox?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Because more stayed, with him,
Because of most continuance,
And longest wearing in my services.

sp.speaker: Fox:
sp.l: What mean you by this wearing? I am sur●●
My wits are worn as thin as a paper-leaf:
But 'tis the fairest end of serving-men,
When we have spent the pleasure of our youth,
E'en sweat it out with painful industry,
To have such itching slaves to eat us out,
Do you so light respect me? I as light
Will make of you, and it come within my power ▪

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Farewell, pull down thy stubborness of 〈◊〉
There breathes no servant of more honesty ▪
Wilt please your kindness, keeper, usher me,
To teach my steps to usher misery.

sp.speaker: Fox:
sp.l: Now Thomas?
What will you do now, Thomas?
Your mistress has discharged you, and your coat, Thomas
Which was as dear to you, as your skin, Thomas,
It is pulled over your ears, what remedy:
Has fox never a hole to hide's head in these extremities
Now I remember my cousin Raynauld lives not far he●●
To him I'll make repair, and feed on country poultry
For a while, till I can cry vindicta on this Duchess.
Well what I'll do my thoughts not yet approve,
Fox will prove true to trust, not false to love,

div.stage: Enter Hughe Tiler, and Jenkin going to work with a trey of tiles and a ladder.

sp.speaker: Til.
sp.l: Jenkin where art thou, hark what a kennel of lies
Gives us our welcome into Kent, set up, come and to th●●●●
stamp the frost out of thy feet into the mortar for me,
I'll catch me a heat or I'll bear it out a'th' stones.

div.stage: Beats his fingers against his sides.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: A good fire would do better with the fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.l: But a pot of ale and a toast would do best of all
With a cold stomach, over go to the cock
And see if he came a'th kind, if his ale will
Make a man crow, we'll leave our implements here
They will not run away, and here's no great crowd
Of people ith' town, but if they be stolen, we may find 'em
Come jenken, nimbly and stay by't.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Whither now wilt thou dispose thyself
From the enraged pursuit of this search
That with their fresh breathings have oft tired thee,
After so many hazards, whence my care
Has sweat in water to redeem my fear,
Must I at last be forced to yield and die
O grief, but who can slip his destiny
They come and I am tired,
Thanks heaven I have found a means
I hope to shelter me in these extremes.

div.stage: Goeth up the ladder and works.

sp.speaker: Cluny.
sp.l: Follow, pursue with swiftness and he's ours,
Soft here's a tiler, we'll inquire of him
Which way he took, sirrah you tiler ho
Durtdauber with a vengeance answer me,
Leave singing of your neck verse, rogue your best
Lest it prove so indeed, you'll answerer '
Tiler ho.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Say you sir, say you.

sp.speaker: Cluny.
sp.l: Say you goodman rascal?
Saw you not a man pass this way
With a speedy course but now.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: He crossed down that way.

sp.speaker: Cluny.
sp.l: How the devil did we miss him?
Tired I hold my life, and ta'ne some barn,
Or privy shed; come let's back, search every nook,
Ransack the bushes, in each corner look.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: How strong my spirit is to call them back,
Armed with the steeled proof of innocence,
That can rebate the edge of tyranny,
Invulnerable innocence she would go,
But yet this flesh is frail and full of fears,
To keep the soul from yond celestial spheres,
Thy will be done my maker, whose great hand
Hath now my life from scorching malice fanned.

sp.speaker: Ienkes,
sp.l: Come away Hugh ti ti tiler,
Now we have lined our backs,
And warmed our bellies,
Let's do our days work in an hour
And drink ourselves drunk all the day after.

sp.speaker: Til.
sp.l: Whope, why the cock ale has spurred thee already

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Thou art a coxcomb to say so, I will run up, and come down my ladder as nimble as a squirrel.

sp.speaker: Tiler,
sp.p: For going up I know not, but thou'lt come down with thy head forward.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Why then that's a trick more than ever thou sawest in thy life, o in my ale I can do any thing, tumble like a elephant.

sp.speaker: Cluny.
sp.l: Now where's this tiler.

sp.speaker: Jenkin.
sp.l: At hand quoth pickpurse,

div.l: Ha you any work for a tiler.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Not so much work sir as you have made for the searcher.
And which way crossed the man?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: Should there not be two hundred of slates, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Answer me hobby-horse,
Which way crossed he you saw enough?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: Who do you speak to sir,
We have forgotten the hobby-horse.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.l: Yes truly sir,
Look well amongst yourselves for him.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: The man, the man sirrah Saunders, that you said you saw.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: That I saw said you, all that I saw was a russet
Gentleman with a toasted cullisance, and he went down
Gutter-lane I assure you.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: That's as true as sands crossed this way, and we not see him.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.p: Did he cross this way and you not see him, the more blind buzzard you.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.p: You told us sirrah enough, he went this way.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Who I, than I told you a lie, for I was then sipping my morning draught.

sp.speaker: Clu
sp.l: Say fellows did not he direct us thither.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: Ay, who I? Jenken the tiler.

sp.speaker: Watch
sp.l: I you.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Bless my slating, is the devil amongst you, that you fall so fast a lying, if I saw any of you before would every slate I have were in your bellies, why do you not know jenken the tiler.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.l: Nor Hugh the good Duchess of Suffolk's man.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: The Duchess man, an heretic.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Nay nay, that's most certain, what's an earwig sir, a good fellow I hope.

sp.speaker: Clu,
sp.l: You shall have that defined,
When you come before my lord ▪

sp.speaker: Tiler,
sp.l: O by no means,
He spits nothing but fire and faggot-sticks.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: No matter, I have ale enough in my belly to
Quench 'em.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: So guard them safe, these villains have conveyed
that traitor sands their fellow, hence.

sp.speaker: Ienk.
sp.l: Not I, I desire you, I renounce and confound you.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Dam up the brick bat's mouth, convey them hence
'Tis they shall pay the price of sands offence.

div.stage: Enter Duchess like a citizen's wife with Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Speak softly, where is nurse, speak softly pr● thee lord, why loiters she, but call her not: soft, soft, w●● creaking shoes hast thou got Cranw. to betray our fear put off them traitors.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thou speakest too loud.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Neither my tongue, nor shoes, can reach an ear

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes Cranwell but they do of jealous fear.
My life is on the hazard of this game
And I mistrust each step will cheat the same.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: O that the poison of this fear were once remove

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We should not then halt here
The poison hath the treason of my foes,
I wish but patience to abide their blows,
But who comes here, nurse, with a candle light
'Tis darkness woman must guide out our fear.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: What light is that there ho?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Nurse what hast thou done?
Disperse away, to lion key begone.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: What ho, will none speak there, awake the guard

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What stay you for, for heaven's sake will you go▪
Good Cranwell, sweet nurse, linger not my woe.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: How will you find that way you yet never w●●

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I'll 'Trust in him that guides the innocent,
Give me my child, and mantle, now heaven's pleasure:
Frewell, come life or death, I'll hug my treasure,
Nay chide not pretty babe, our enemies come
Thy crying will pronounce thy mother's dome.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: She's gone, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Not far, but be thou still
This gate may shade us from their envious will.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Gone, gone, pursue her or we are undone.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O fear what art thou! lend me wings to file,
Direct me in this plunge of misery,
Nature has taught the child obedience,
Thou hast been humble to thy mother's wish,
O let me kiss these duteous lips of thine,
That would not kill thy mother with a cry,
Now forward whither heaven directs, for I
Can guide no better than thine infancy,
Here are two pilgrims bound to lion-key,
And neither knows one footstep of the way,
Return you, then 'tis time to shift me hence.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Search every corner, here, behind this gate
Her mantle, o the luck, had we but stayed
To search this nook, when fury bore us hence
With violence to overtake her course,
We had prevented her intended scape
But what heaven would not, could not, 'tis decreed,
Her innocent life, should not by envy bleed:
But here we stint not, to pursue her flight,
I know 'twill boil up bonners rancorous spite.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Thus far, but heaven knows where we have escaped
The eager pursuit of our enemies,
Having for guidance my attentive fear,
Still I look back, still start my tired feet,
Which never till now measured London street,
My honours scorned that custom, they would ride,
Now forced to walk, more weary pain to bide:
Thou shalt not do so child, I'll carry thee
In sorrows arms to welcome misery,
Custom must steel thy youth with pinching want,
That thy great birth, in age may bear with scant,
Sleep peaceably sweet duck, and make no noise
Methinks each step is deaths arresting voice,
We shall meet nurse anon, a dug will come
To please my quiet infant, when, nurse, when?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Who's that calls nurse?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ay me I am o'erheard.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Master Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Who goes there? Nurse?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Nurse:
sp.l: My sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Whist honest nurse? how strangely are we 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: It is the place where you appointed us.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Then heaven is gracious to my ignorance,
For had this night worn on the pride of day,
By I it could not have found out the way.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Are you not weary madam?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Admit I be, let patience ease all, there's no 〈◊〉
Within cry. For Gravesend ho.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What's that, he frighted me.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: They call for their passengers to Graves-end.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Pass we our fears with them, there stays at lee
A bark that will redeem our liberty,
If you dare venture, with my fortunes go,
A tide of joy, may turn this stream of woe.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: How you resolve of me, I know not, try,
And when I shrink, brand me with infamy.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: In heaven's name, on then, fellows all in sorrow,
When we stand need, we'll mutual comfort borrow.

div.stage: Enter bonner, Gardner, Cluny, Jenkin and Tiler, guarded.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My lord sit down, stand forth thou hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: I never drunk hippocras in my life sir,
'Twas strong ale that I am guilty of.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Cluny give evidence against this wretch,
Hath set his hand to help a traitor hence.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: Indeed my lord I am no traitor, I am a tiler,
sp.p: Cluny tells your lordship a fable, we saw no such man, not we.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: No, wilt thou obstinately stand in it,
Didst not thou lend him a disguise, employ him
Amongst other labourers about thy work,
And yet wilt thou deny thou art no traitor.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Slave, villain, dog,
Have we not here the honest testimony
Of mine own parator, that saw him clothed
In thy apparel, and darest thou deny it,
Faggots, faggots, hence toth' stake with him.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: O good my lord, I shall never endure it,
I was once but burned ith' hand, and I have been
The worse fort ever since, do but hear me,
Prove that I had any other apparel this seven years,
Then that you see upon my back, and burn me not,
But cut me into rashers, and broil me for carbonadoes.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My lords as I am Cluny, and your parator,
This counterfeit simplicitude was he,
That twixt the hours of 12. and 1. at noon,
Conveyed the impious traitor from our search,
By shifting him into his homely rags.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Twixt 12. and 1. ne'er trust me, but at that 〈◊〉 time I and my fellow here, (Canst thou speak nothing thyself) were at dinner at mother Puttocks, with a pi●● of a tripe and a black-pudding, by the same token th●● was a candle's end in't as long as my thumb.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: So, so, you're a cunning knave, but sirrah, sirrah,
This cannot serve your turn, you rescued him,
And that by'th law is held as capital,
As if thyself wert guilty of the crime.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: His crime my lord is it not manifest,
That he's a favourer of these schismatics,
And what is that but flat rebellion.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Go too, he must fry fort, he, shall I say the wo●
Bonner that ere long will purge this land with bonfires,
We come not with the olive branch of peace,
But with the sword of justice, these hydras-heads will fly
Be flourishing, unless at once we give't a fatal stroke,
Let them convert to ashes, let them burn,
So shall the state be quiet ● how now, what news?
What have you caught the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Most strangely sir, she did escape my hands,
Besides at Billingsgate have I kept narrow search,
Yet for my life could set no eye on her.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: But we have all this while ta'ne a wrong course
Shall we imagine being hunted thus:
She would commit the safeguard of her life
To common passage, where she was assured
There would be diligent weight laid for her:
No, she's more subtle, all the world, my lord,
shall not persuade, but she's in England still,
In Margot, Lee, or some such bordering town.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: And in good time I met a man of hers,
One fox, my lord, a fellow, as it seems,
Disgraced by her, that told me we were wide
In that we went about.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Where met you him.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Coming from Algate.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Would he not confess
Which way his lady mistress was escaped?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: With much ado my lords, with threats and promises,
At last he told me he would bring
Where we might trace her, and entrap her too.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why brought you not that fellow to our presence?
He shall have dispensation how he will,
So he be trusty, and perform his word.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: He promised faithfully to meet me here.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Well if he come, your ear.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Now fox devise to qualify
Thy nature to thy name,
These be mere cannibals
That take no pleasure but in sucking blood,
And though unluckily it was thy chance,
To fall into their hands, yet be not thou
( however outward grievances may urge)
A traitor to thy lady; smooth with these,
That under colour to betray the Duchess,
She may have safer liberty to pass.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: See my lords, he's come.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Come hither sirrah, you did serve the Duchess,
And 'tis no doubt but you can give us notice
Which way she's fled, stand no upon nice terms
As fearing to incur some deadly sin,
But tell us plainly which way she is gone.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My lords, I cannot readily discover
Which way she's gone, by reason I have been
Long in disgrace, and quite dismissed the house,
But sure it is, she went disguised from hence,
And 'tis not possible but she must lurk,
Within some haven town near to the coast.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: What town, as thou imaginest?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My lords I think towards Dover,
Or the downs of Kent.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Nay that's not likely, soft, some
News I hope.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Health to this honourable presence,
I come to certify your lordships all,
That as we kept the ports on Essex side,
'Twas credibly reported, that the Duchess
With little or no train, is lodged in Lee,
And for she is disguised, and our commission
Expired the date, we crave a fresh supply,
And some direction how to intercept her.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: No better means than to renew our warrant,
And send this fellow with it that doth know her,
Into what shape soe'er she be transformed.
It shall be so, I thank thee pursyvant
For thy good news, it glads me at the heart,
I shall at length be even with this proud Duchess,
At Lee in Essex, o 'tis excellent:
But I will tell you how't shall be my lord,
Fox shall not go alone, Cluny and I
Will bear him company, and withal, ha, ha,
I cannot choose but laugh to tell the rest,
As she's disguised to hide her from my sight,
So will I be, to take her, in her slight,
Is it not good, is it not rare my lord,
Nay is it not the best that ere you heard,
When subtlety by fraud shall be debarred,
I warrant you she's ours Cluny, fox come hither,
Provide you straight, fox thou shalt go with me,
Ha, wilt thou not.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: (A plague upon you,) I must answer, I.
Howe'er my heart abhor this treachery,
My lord I will.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why now thou pleasest me,
And I will richly recompense thy pains,
But for we will not, our affairs at home,
In the mean time be slacked, or intermitted,
You my good lords shall have a special care
About it straight, fox, Cluny, follow me,
This is to Bonner chief felicity.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Fox, and Ienken.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Yes, I will follow,
Though not further ye,
I trust this is a means ordained of heaven,
To bridle this bloodsuckers cruelty,
But how now, what art thou.

sp.speaker: Ienken.
sp.p: Marry sir an honest man and a tiler, that was sent for hither to be examined about wan m. sands, and it seems for joy they have to know where the Duchess is, they have forgotten me, what were I best to do.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: What else but get thee home unto thy house,
Away be packing, since they have forgotten thee,
Do not thou tarry to revive their memory.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.l: Nay if I put them in mind on't, let me be choked,
For want of drink, since ale thou art so lucky,
I'll take the tother pot while it is nappy.

div.head: Actus tertius.
div.stage: Enter Duchess, Cranwell, nurse, the child, sands, master Goseling a merchant.

sp.speaker: Goseli.
sp.l: Most honoured princes, think yourself as safe
In my protection at this town of Lee,
As in the strongest hold you do possess.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Good m. Goseling now we fly to you
As to our harbour, in your hands it lies,
Either to comfort, or confound our lives?

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: We now are chased by many savage men,
That with bloodthirstiness pursue our deaths,
Being yet within the closure of their arms,
And desperate of all hope to you we fly.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Cousin goseling 'mongst a world of other men
The providence of heaven chose out you,
Either to be made famous for true faith,
Or by disloyal dealing infamous,
Presuming on your perfect honesty,
I brought my noble mistress, this grave doctor,
This infant lady, and present us all,
To your safe conduct: o betray our lives,
Bonner will give you gold, woe to that good
That bad men get, by selling guiltless blood,
If any such thought have possessed your heart,
Make merchandise of mine, let these escape,
For these are precious in the eyes of heaven,
Let them depart, lead me to Bonner first,
Happy my blood, to quench his raging thirst.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Cousin I wonder, what desert of mine
Hath bred in you this bad opinion,
But I impute it rather to the zeal
You bear your lady's safety, than the thought
of any treason you discern in me,
Madam my life, yet out of danger's gripe,
I thrust into your peril, witness heaven,
I take upon me to conceal your flight,
And now I am as deep in bonners hate
As near to danger, as the next to death,
Be confident in me, the zeal I bear,
To the sincere profession of the truth,
Is a sure guard for you to trust upon.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The poorest princes, only rich in faith,
Will pay you a large bounty of her prayers,
Remember than you call me mistress white,
For by that name I passed from Billingsgate,
Thence to Graves-end, and so from thence to Lee,
Where under your protection we remain.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: In every place we here the hue and cry,
Pursue our fearful flight, in every town
We hear the voice of persecution.

sp.speaker: Craenw.
sp.l: And hark I here the officers within
If we be known, we are but dead.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Tush mistress white,
That name shall give free scope unto your flight.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Good you, good even m. Gosseling,
Good you, good even.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Welcome good m. Constable,
What's the news with you ▪

sp.speaker: Constable ▪
sp.p: Marry we have a warrant here from the high commission, to seek for a Duchess, and certain other people, that are in her company, as doctor sands, and one master Cranwell, her gentleman-usher, we are commanded to search your house for such suspected persons.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: See m. Constable, with me remains
No more than these, if mistress white my daughter,
Come with her child, and nurse to visit me,
with this her husband, this her husband's father,
If you think her a Duchess, him a doctor,
Than you may apprehend them at your pleasure,
If not, you had best to make a further search,
For I protest, no stranger more than these,
Harbours within my roof.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: I take your word sir, and yet I will not, I will sea
She a Duchess bless her good woman,
Good mistress white you're welcome to Lee, as I may say wit●
We have an honest neighbour of your father,
Is this your child, heaven bless the little mops,
Alack, alack, it is as like the grandsire
As ever it may look, my pretty duck.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Where's m. Constable, have you made search
In these suspicious houses.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Good heaven protect us, now we are betrayed,
This villain will, I fear, discover us.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I know her, them, and all.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Good m. Goseling stand to us now,
Or we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Get you into my house.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Stand there attend there m. Constable,
My m. doctor Bonner in disguise,
Stays at the gate, let me survey these parties.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Thou knowest us fox, we have been fellow va●●
Confer the years past, with the present times,
And it will make thy flinty heart relent.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: O fox, she hath been the most honoured mistress
That ever servant served, stay me,
And whilst their bloody hands are busied,
With seizing me, let her, and these escape.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Peace fellow, now no fellows, thy mistr. when 〈◊〉
In prosperity, turned me off, and therefore I will not know
her in extremity.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Wilt thou not know her in extremity,
Ungrateful villain.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: No sir, I will not, I come to look a Duchess,
Woman be gone, I know thee not, thou a Doct, thou a dunce,
Get thee gone, Cranwell I knew, he was my fellow servant,
Thee I know not, thou art a paltry fellow,
Away goseling, take in your geese,
Ship them at your pleasure, when the coast is clear,
I myself will give you a watchword.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: The fellow may mean well, let us withdraw.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I now perceive, I have done his faith much wrong,
His heart has no relation to his tongue.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Away, where's the constable.
Here's neither Cranwell, sands, Duchess, nor child,
Go call in my lord Bonner.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What hast thou found them fox?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My lord we had a wrong intelligence,
But thus you shall surprise them, pass they cannot
But by this way, now will we watch these passages,
For now the tide's at height, if they intend
To ship themselves, it must be presently,
Place yourself here, directly by this well,
By you Cluny, here I mean to stand,
Guard that place well, by me this shall be manned.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Stand by me Cluny, fox, I'll pay thee well,
If by thy means we catch these miscreants,
'Twill be thy making fox, m. Constable where will you stand.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Let him keep that way, that bears to landward,
That way, I am sure they will not take,
Go make a strong watch there.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: I warrant you m. fox, let us alone to guard that passage.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My lord, you had best sit for your ease.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O I could watch hours, days, nights, months, years
So I might see their hearts weep bloody tears.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Look you stand sure lord Bonner, for I hope,
Anon you'll need a bucket, and a rope.

div.stage: Enter Goseling, Duchess, sands, Cranwell, nurse, and child.

sp.speaker: Gose.
sp.l: Keep close together, lest you lose your train,
My bark is ready to receive you straight,
That way you need must take, I'll not be seen,
Heaven be your guide, with me you have not been.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Good sir farewell, my prayers on you attend,
I will report you for a prince's friend.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Stand, trust me and keep on,
Whate'er you see shrink not, away begone,
My lord they come, they come, away, away.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Help, help, for heaven's sake help.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My lord is in the well.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: A rope for Bishop Bonner, Cluny run,
Call help, a rope, or we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: I'll to the watch for help.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Help, help, good fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Soft Bonner, not too fast
Here is no coming out till they be past,
My arms too short my lord, a rope is coming.

div.stage: Enter Cluny, constable, watch, with ropes.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Here in this well, ropes, ropes my masters.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: By this they are far enough,
Well done my masters, lends your hands,
Draw Du● out of the ditch.
Draw, pull, help all, so, so, well done.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O fox o Cluny, o my masters all,
I am almost drowned, o lead me to some fire.
O fox, what meanest thou to rush with such rude force.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: What would you have me do, I saw them coming,
And I had not the power to stay myself.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And are they passed.

sp.speaker: Gose.
sp.l: What stand you trifling here, what seek you for?
If for the Duchess, if for doctor sands,
For Cranwell, and the rest, they in disguise,
Are got aboard a ship, and with full sails,
Fly from the shore.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Thou tellst me a sad tale,
Post fox, run Cluny, hire a ●arke with speed,
Goseling we were suspicious of thy faith,
But by this message, thou hast cleared thyself,
See goseling, I am almost drowned.

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.l: I am sorry for your honour, that you 'scaped.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Tush we trifle time in their vain pursuit,
Thou shalt have gold fox; Cluny, thou reward,
Help me to fire good goseling, fox away,
We lose much expedition by thy stay.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I'll after them my lord.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: May all things prosper to thy hearts desire,
Come goseling, prithee lead me to a fire.

div.stage: Enter bartie, and Pericell a Walloune.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: And as I told you sir, with that excuse,
I grounded this my colourable passage,
And sent a ship, which stays for her at Lee,
Where by appointment she had promised meeting,
But she is so watched, so guarded, and so barred,
Of her true servants presence and access,
That I despair of her arrival here.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Good m. Bertie, cheer your drooping thoughts,
We are walloons, but in subjection,
and strict obedience to the church of Rome,
Rewards and promises, are sent abroad,
To every foreign prince, and burgomaster,
To stay the Duchess, for the rumor runs,
She is escaped already from her house.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis very certain m. Perecell,
Now shall we hear some news,
Here's doctor Sands.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: News of the Duchess, that will please but ill,
I will forbear to speak of our escapes,
All which were winged, with fortune, and success,
And tell you of one hapless accident,
We all took ship at Lee, but not together,
For I alone passed in a Hollander,
No sooner did the wind blow from the shore,
But rose a tempest, which dispersed our ships,
And we might see the bark wherein she went,
By violence of the waves forced back again,
Even to the haven's mouth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Even to deaths lean arms,
Thy tragic news, hath slain me m. sands,
We are as one, and what beside her person,
I feel in a true essence of her grief.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: In these extremes, 'tis good to hope the best.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O m. Perecill, the worst of ills,
Falls on her head, and can I hope the best,
She's like a lamb, trapped with a herd of wolves,
A harmless dove amongst a thousand hawks,
If she returned, what providence can save,
A body doomed already to the grave.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: See m. Bertie, lift up your sad eyes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Bertie.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: O see the meeting of two faithful souls,
What a sweet union it doth make of hearts,
When one another mutual joy imparts.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Defer the story, of our dangers past,
To acquaint us with some comfortable aid.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: O pardon me one minute gentle madam,
If I delay your fair request a little,
To take my fellow servants by the hand,
Good m. Cranwell, the firm loyalty,
You bear you mistress, in her great extremes,
Shall be recorded in a book of brass.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Alas I have scanted of my duty much,
My liberal will's joined with unable power,
With my true service I do join my life,
And owe them both, unto your princely wife.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You are a mirror, nurse, so art thou,
Thy noble carriage, thus I kiss with joy,
Alas poor lady, thou, ere thou canst go,
Art forced to leave thy country, thy return,
Will make them smile, that now are forced to mourn,
Thy infancy in pilgrimage is spent,
Yet thy abode hereafter shall be Kent,
And be an honoured countess of that name,
For so my true divining spirits do aim.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What gentleman is that.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: 'Tis a Walloone Feris de Ryviers, alias Perecell.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: May we repose with him?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Madam you may not,
Neither in this place may I challenge you,
For I am noted, and your coming hither,
Both promised, and expected by great men,
Who to surprise you, have received reward,
All ports are laid, all passages are stopped,
Search, and inquiry posts through every town.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Madam 'tis true, nor would I have you stay,
In Emden long, for you are laid for here.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What shall we then do?

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Madam, let's to Santon,
Let m. Bertie stay with Perecell,
And meet us there hereafter.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Content, let it be so,
Never two lovers, married to more woe,
Here meet we, and here part we, o short pleasure,
Which fortune serves us, in too small a measure.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My body is divided in the midst,
That way goes half my heart, and this way tother,
Necessity thy stern deeds I beshrew,
That thy rude hand, gives us the parting blow,
At Santon I will meet you madam, here
I dare not know you, so adieu my dear.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Berty farewell, to Santon bound we are,
With these companions, and our conduct care,
You people happy in a land of peace,
That joy your consciences, with the world's increase,
Look with indifference into my sad life,
Here my poor husband, dares not know his wife,
And I a prince's, to avoid like danger,
Must use my own dear husband, as a stranger,
Towards Santon we, through deserts, any way,
Though all should leave me, I for grief must stay.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam, you see what strictness, we are forced to.
Let's wing our feet, till we can get to Santon,

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Madam, let me admire your constancy,
For heaven hath proved your patience every way,
Yet you are confident, and more your zeal to try,
You're forced your loyal husband to deny,

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Then what pale trembling cowards heart would faint,
To wade through danger with so pure a saint?

sp.speaker: 1. Thief.
sp.l: A booty, stend, despoil them, down with them.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We are beset with thieves.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Sands, thou must fly,
For weaponless, thou canst no mastery try.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: 1. Thief.
sp.l: Pursue them not, let's seize on them that stay,

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Slaves, you have murdered me.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: No matter, seize on her, and rifle both,
Ha, by my faith a gallant lusty wench,
'Tis the best booty, that we met this month.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O my true servant's death, doth grieve me more,
Than all the sorrows that I felt before.

div.stage: They draw her aside to rifle her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am jealous of the safety of my wife,
And to escape the better through the woods,
I have clothed myself thus in an outlaw's shape,
O, sight of ruth, my fellow Cranwell slain:
My wife grasped in the arms of ravishers,
Then heaven instruct me with some present means,
That I may find some aid to rescue them,
I have it, a booty, a booty, a brave booty:
But we want help, and aid to compass it,
Four wealthy merchants, are come down this hill,
Some little aid, and we shall share them all.

sp.speaker: 2. Thief.
sp.l: Some of you look to see the woman safe,
I'll help to take the booty.

sp.speaker: 3. Thief.
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: 1. Thief.
sp.l: One bird ith' hand's worth two ith' bush:
I'll take my present purchase.

sp.speaker: 2. Thief.
sp.l: We'll share a both sides, come conduct us to them.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I will, stir not from hence with her,
Till we return.

sp.speaker: 1. Thief.
sp.l: My life for yours, come, will you uncase.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Do not disrobe me of my clothes, as you're a man.

sp.speaker: 1. Thief.
sp.l: Tut, stand not upon terms,
I love to see a woman naked.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Defend me heaven.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: So ho, ho, I have lost a jewel,
And left it here behind, when I departed hence.

sp.speaker: 1. Thief.
sp.l: What value.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: More precious than thy soul, and this it is,
Villain, think not to scape, your mates are far enough ▪

sp.speaker: 1. Thief.
sp.l: How goodman rascal.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Thus, villain, for the world,
I would not stain my hands with thy base blood:
But rascal, I will bind you to the peace,
So now, let this ditch shelter you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My Berty? heaven be praised,
Though I am robbed of all the wealth I have,
I am rich enough, in my possessing thee,

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Is m. Cranwell slain?

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: But sorely hurt, and I am near to death.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Bind up your wounds, with this white handkerchief 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Bertie,
sp.l: I am so used to misery, 〈◊〉
That it seems nothing, where's the nurse and child?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: O cross on cross, let's look about the woods ▪

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My Susan lost, I will not stir one foot,
But to the villains be a second prey,
Unless I find her.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Lend me your hand dear sir, get I once up,
I'll spend the remnant of my blood that's left,
In search of my young mistress.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: O whither shall I fly, to save my life,
From the rude hands of these fell ravishers?
My hapless lady, and her husband both,
By this, have felt the cruel stroke of death,
Or which is worse, are captive led away,
sp.stage: Noise within so ho, ho nurse
sp.l: And to the vulture's gripes become a prey,
o hark, I hear them coming, hence begone,
Hard is thy hap, that must be left alone,
Dear babe forgive me, I am forced for life,
To ease my carriage, leave thee to their strife.
On forwards madam, this way they are gone,
Heaven be propitious, direct us in our search.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Amen, amen.

div.stage: Enter Cranwell staggering, and falls near the bush where the child is.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: O I am lost, sink body to the earth,
Ascend my soul, amongst saints receive new birth.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Help Bertie, help, 'tis Cranwell faints, o help.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Speak to me man, look up, some wound belike
Is yet unstopped, from whence proceeds this large effusion,
It's here, lend me some linen, so, so, he comes again,
And see heavens bounty, he at once hath given,
Your servant, and your child: look madam, see,
Thrown in a bush, and smiles, and laughs at ye.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Having my husband, child, and this my servant,
I am the richest princes on the earth,
But Berty, where's the nurse, and doctor sands.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Both fled, but wherefore madam look you pale.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O Berty, I do feel the time approach
Of my delivery, o for help of women.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: What shall we do, I am beyond myself.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Cranwell, what town is this that stands before.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Madam, they call it weezle.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Go, begone,
Thy looks pleads for a cunning surgeon,
We shall not need, thy help, thy wound is deep,
But stay you Bertie, you the child must keep.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Madam, this storm, the cold, and my deep wounds,
May well excuse me, till my hurts are dressed.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Be gone I say.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How fare you madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Sick I am, heaven knows,
Ready to die, with these my pinching throws,
It rains, and hails, and snows, and blows at once,
Where Berty, may we hide us from this storm.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Here in this church-porch, madam pray remonst

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Help, and lead me thither, now lay the Ch●● down Ber●
Go gather sticks, to help to make a fire,
More plagues my sins do merit year by year,
But these, good heavens, are more than I can bear.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Alas, alas, this is a homely place,
To bring a Princess of such state to bed,
A wide church-porch, is made her bedchamber,
And the cold stones her couch, here are no curtains,
But the bleak winds, could clouds and storms of hay
And they begird her round, heaven for thy mercy,
This poor distressed princes shield and save,
Whose cold head lies upon some dead man's grave,
Here comes the sexton, I will speak to him,
It may be, he may help us to relief.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: God's sacrament vat maukt ye dare.

sp.speaker: Bert,
sp.l: Patience good sir.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Vat bedlers in den kerke, looped hence strax.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Uncivil fellow, what thou speakest, I know no ▪
But thy ill meaning by thy deeds, I guess:
Take that to teach thee more civility.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Out skellum one hundred thousand devil.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Still fortune is against us, this base fellow
Will raise some tumult to betray our lives,
Yet yonder comes and man of gravity,
It may be he can speak the Latin tongue,
In that I'll let him understand my grief:
Optime et ornatissime vir, audi quaeso.

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.l: Quis es qui tot clamoribus, et tanta exclamatione,
Non modo divinum cenatorij locum irreverenter et
Orrose occupas, at urbem tam claram civesque et senatores,
Propter etates svas adoratissimas tam flactiose disturbas.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Si cum front tam generosa cour tuum humanum consentire
Videtur, infortunij nostri miserere.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Erasmus roterodamus propter miserias vestras toto cord
Dolet, colo perfectiones et virtutes, quas intimo meo animo
Complectar, multi pendo.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Is this Erasmus born in Rotterdam,
He that so highly loved sir Thomas more?

sp.speaker: Erasm.
sp.l: Portate hanc ad domum francisci de rivers alias Perecell
Sic domino dominaeque erasmus rotero damus omnibus
Officijs est observantissimus.

div.stage: They bear her off in a chair. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Within this town hath Perecell a house,
There, by the credit of this learned man ▪
We have got harbour till the month expire,
In which her heavy burden may be eased,
Good heaven look down upon her misery,
Comfort her in her grief, strengthen her weakness,
Lay not our woes to wretched bonners charge,
Free her sweet heaven, by thy almighty hand,
That we may once revisit our own land.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Now cheer yourself dear sir, here is a time,
To breathe a space, this town's a quiet port,
from the tempestuous gusts of Bonners hate.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Some refuge I confess, but the distressed Dutch ▪
In childbed torment is a fresh alarum
Of new sprung care, I cannot be at quiet,
Until her safe delivery be passed.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Doubt not of that, the powerful hand of heaven
In such extremities is ever strong.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Good heaven, when I recount the miseries
We have already passed, methinks the lottery
Of cruel fortune, should be quite exhaust,
And yet when I record the name of Bonner,
With his desire to become great by blood,
The greater part of woe seems still behind.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Doubtless he's of a most pernicious spirit,
But he that hath restrained his envious rage,
And hitherto repulsed him, still will curb him.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I trust he will, Cranwell I prithee step,
And listen from the women what good news.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Pray save that labour, we can bring the news

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Welcome good doctor sands,
What; in good health?

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Sir, thanks to heaven, who never leaves his o●●
Nor suffers them to perish in distress.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How fares the Duchess.
Gentle host resolve me.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Happy and well, cheer your declining thought
Well that her perilous conflict hath an end,
And happy that to comfort her withal,
There's born this day a young lord Willoughby.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: A boy.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: A goodly boy m. Bertie.
And one in whom already doth appear,
These signs of courage, to revenge your wrongs.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Good heaven I thank thee,
This your news dear friend,
Is as a summons after death to life, the preservation
Of his mother in travel, was wondrous strange,
The place where he is born is strange,
The loving hands, that did first entertain
His presence to this pilgrimage of life,
Are likewise strange, then as his birth hath been,
So shall his name, we'll call him Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: A stranger to his country by that name,
But by his deeds hereafter time may prove,
None more adventured for his countries' love.

div.stage: A drum beats a soft march.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As it please his stars, but soft,
What drum is this, some gall I fear,
To intermix our sweet,
Some sorrow to confound this sudden joy.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Your servant fox did vow to bring you word,
If any hurt were secretly pretended.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Is fox arrived, upon what cause,
Is fox arrived, upon what cause
Is he passed over, do you know gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Himself make answer for himself.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Sir, be not you dismayed, in brief these drums,
And those that after these sad music dance,
Are none that wish you, nor the Duchess good,
A captain sent from England, and the bloodhound Cluny,
With them the Duke of Brunswick, clad in arms,
And at the least, ten ensigns after him,
These howe'er they vizard their intents,
With other colour, as to vex the emperor,
Yet their whole purpose, is to look for you,
The gates, and walls, are every way beset,
and through the town, a privy search begun,
And but you presently devise some means,
To scape from hence, they'll take you in your lodging.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: Escape, there's now no time to talk of scape,
No, no, the secret providence of heaven,
Hath so ordained, we should be Bonners thrall,
And welcome wished death, the end of all.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: My mind presageth of a better speed.
What m. Bertie why not now escape,
As well as heretofore.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: How can that be,
The painful Duchess, lying now in childbed.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Is there no art, no means to blind their eyes.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: You are so many of you, 'tis impossible,
Besides the Duchess, she cannot remove.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: O, were she safe, I cared not for my life.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Nor I for mine.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Nor I, had I ten thousand lives,

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Cease you your passions, my brain hath tutor 〈◊〉
And in a cunning plot shall set you free.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do that, and Bertie is for ever thine.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Fox, and his sword, for that will be thy slave.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Thy friendship will I bear unto my grave.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What thou attemptest,
My prayers shall help to second.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: I neither do expect thanks, nor reward,
But what I do is of mere charity,
Then list unto me, there's a friend of mine,
A country gentleman, not far from hence,
Whose brother late returned from the wars,
And falling sick, within the city here,
Died some few days since, now this gentleman,
Because his brother shall be buried,
Amongst his ancestors, decrees this night,
To have his body in a wagon brought,
Home to the parish church, where he remains,
and for that purpose hath his servants sent,
To see it safe conveyed: a waggon like to theirs,
Covered with black, shall be provided straight,
Into the which, by help of women's hands,
The Duchess, and her infant shall be lifted,
You, and the rest disguised in mourning weeds,
Shall follow after as the guard,
And in the dead man's name without suspect,
Pass by the soldiers, who if they chance,
To question who you are,
The burghers being by, and made acquainted,
With such a hearse, that is to pass that way,
Will quickly answer them, without more search,
How like you this.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It will I hope prove currant.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: The pretext is fit, and for the Duchess ease:

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Fox has no more sense than a battle-door,
If in his judgement, we already be not
Delivered from the mischief of their hands.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Come I'll provide you all things necessary.
And after pray for your success therein.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I'll back to them, and help you what I can.

div.stage: Enter Brunswick, L. Paget, portgrave, Cluny, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Great Duke of Brunswick, this your flexible,
And courteous disposition of your troops,
To be for England's service, shall receive
The due belongeth to so great a merit.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: Noble captain, I were much to be condemned,
If I neglect my duty to the church,
But are you sure, these fugitives are here?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Cluny, thou toldst me, that thou sawest a man
Of theirs, since we beset the town waste true?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Yes noble captain, Cranwell the Duchess usher,
and there's no question, but the rest are here,

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well then captain, the other ports being guard
Here with this company we'll keep our station,
Where is the portgrave? have you sent abroad,
Sufficient search amongst the private houses?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: We have my lord.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: They cannot be in weasel,
But either coming forth, or lurking here,
They must in all sorts be discovered by us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: O they are politic, and passing subtle,
And if or art, or policy, can help them,
There's in their company, an instrument.
Can plot a hundred wales for their escape.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Let them express their cunning, if they can,
And scape our hands, now we have scented them.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: How now my lord, o I am out of breath,
In coming to you, yet I hope my haste,
Is little for your purpose, they are coming,
Stand on your guard, for this way they must pass,
There's Bertie, Cranwell, sands, with them the Duchess,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: 'Twas well done fox, there's thy reward, stand close
Or, now, or never, let us show our care, stand, who got them

div.stage: Enter four, bearing a hearse, Bertie, sands, Cranwell, mourners.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: Some funeral it seems.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: It may be some device procured by them,
So to escape the danger of our watch, stand.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: I can assure your lordship, 'tis not so,
This is the body of young Vandermast,
Whose brother dwelling some four leagues from hence,
Although he died here, yet will have him buried,
Whereas his ancestors are all entombed,
And for that cause, hath sent his servants for him.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: Is it no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: No mighty prince,
And would to heaven it had not been so now:

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Pass then, pass, it is not you we look for.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: What was this Vandermast, a citizen?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: No my good lord, he was a soldier,
A proper gentleman, and one had served
The emperor, and others in their wars,
Yet was ordained, to end his days at home.

sp.speaker: Bruns
sp.l: A thing no more than usual, but how now,
What's here, another funeral? nay then
It is a hazard, we are all deluded.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My thoughts began to prophecy as much,
Speak, are not you the parties that even now
Came this way, with a mourning funeral.

sp.speaker: 1. mour.
sp.l: Not we my lord, this is the first appearance,
We made this evening.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: What have you there concealed.

sp.speaker: 1. mour.
sp.l: Nothing my lord, but a dead body coffined,
The brother of our m. late deceased.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Ay, this is Vandermast, the other past,
Upon my life, was Barty, and the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: They were unwilling to look up methought .

sp.speaker: Bruns:
sp.l: And he that spoke, spoke with a feigned voice.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: 'Twas they, 'twas they, o, I could tear my hair,
To think we were so grossly overseen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I said as much, come let us follow them,
Send horsemen out, to every quarter straight,
My lord of Brunswick.

sp.speaker: Bruns:
sp.l: You need not bid me ride,
This oversight, hath clapped wings to my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Now for some pretty policy again,
To lead them forth the way, until the Duchess,
May reach Polonia, and deserve the prize,
Fox play thy part, some stratagem devise.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Where sits the wind, no news from german
If those malicious fugitives be ta'en,
Our officers I fear, neglect their charge,
Our captain deals but coldly with the states.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I dreamt my lord, that Bertie and the Duchess ▪
Were both advanced upon a regal throne,
And had their temples wreathed with glittering gold.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: That throne do I interpret, is the stage
Of horrid death, these wreathes of gold, bright flames,
That shall not only circle in their brows,
But wind about their bodies, till they waste,
And be converted to a heap of ashes,
Methinks this work of ours goes slowly forward,
The air of England freezeth for defect
Of burning meteors, to keep it warm.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: See yet my lord, there hath of late been sacrificed
In sundry places, many persons, of several qualities,
Whose names were tedious to relate.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Tut this is nothing, every town should blaze,
And every street, in every town look red,
With glowing cinders of the miscreants:
Till like to cockle, they were quite extinct,
And nothing seen to flourish but pure corn:
The morning spends apace, where are these knaves,
Appointed to bring faggots for the fire,
Wherein bold Latimer, and Ridley must expire.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: They come my lord.

sp.speaker: Bonner.
sp.l: Fie on you loitering knaves,
