Why make you not more haste, be gone, I say,
And see the stake, and every thing be ready,
See how I am still procrastinated,
The mayor of Oxford, means to dine I think,
Before he bring the prisoners to the stake,
How now? where are they?

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.l: Hard at hand my lord,
But the weak age of Latimer is such,
They cannot come so fast, as else they would,
Besides some disputations as they pass,
Had with the scholars, hath detained their speed.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: He have no disputations, bring them on.

div.stage: Enter Latimer, and Ridley, with halberds.

sp.speaker: Ridley.
sp.l: Come brother Latimer, lend me your arm,
The weak, the weak, but not the blind, the blind,
This day in Oxford, shall be seen to guide.

sp.speaker: Lati.
sp.l: My heart is jocund, brother Ridley, still,
And in my spirit, I fly unto yond place,
But these weak withered saplings are too blame,
These legs of mine, that having now at least,
Full four score and eight winter's done me service,
Should now deceive me trust me, but my soul is
Linked in charity, with all the world,
I could be well content, to chide with them.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: These are those self justifying publicans,
Away with them, conduct them to the fire.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Come, come, spend no time in talk,
Will you convert, be sorry for your crime,
And you shall yet find favour with the Queen.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Fie, fie, spit at them, offer them no mercy.

sp.speaker: Ridley.
sp.l: Proceed in scorn, so was our master used,
The servants are 〈◊〉 better than their lord,

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Drag them away there, hence away I say.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Stay, stay.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Which voice is that.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Some one that's prisoner in Bocardo here,

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: O stay my lords, whom lead you there to
The reverent fathers, Ridley, and Latimer?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I Cranmer, but more favour rests for thee,
Because thou art converted from thine errors.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Did you not tell me, they were likewise change ▪
And have you falsely circumvented me?
O heaven, forgive my traitorous revolt,
And you the chosen vessels of his love,
Dear Latimer, sweet Ridley pardon me,
To make amends, I'll come and die with you.

sp.speaker: Lati.
sp.l: As your revolt, grave Cranmer, was our grief,
So to hear these repentant graceful words,
Infuse our hearts with joy, beyond compare.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Will Cranmer then turn, and return again.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: To turn to virtue never comes too late.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Thy recantation underneath thy hand,
Is published, and wilt thou now contradict it.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Bonner, to cut off needless circumstance,
Let this declare my resolution,
This hand that writ that faithless recantation,
Since I am barred from dying with my friends,
Mark how I punish in this lingering flame,
It shall burn off, as an assured sign,
Hereafter of my constant martyrdom,
No scandal shall be left by my default,
Open you heavens, and entertain my willing sacrifice,
Yet this is but an earnest of that love,
hereafter shall in greater measure shine.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Jailor pull down that schismatic,
Lodge him within the dungeon, load his joints
With iron fetters, let him fast from meat,
And have no comfort, but continual checks, dispatch, I say.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Farewell religious mates,
What earth doth separate, I hope ere long,
Shall meet in heaven, spite of proud Bonners tongue.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Farewell kind brother, ne'er decline no more,
But follow us, as we have gone before.

sp.speaker: Laty.
sp.l: What stay we for, my quiet thoughts desire,
To clothe this flesh, in purple robes of fire.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: You shall not need to urge our expedition,
Lead them away, their tragedy once ended,
We will prepare attentive ears to hear,
News of the Duchess landing prisoner.

div.stage: Enter Duchess, and Bertie, with their children.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yet we have scaped the danger of our foes,
And I that whilom was exceeding weak,
Through my hard travel in this infant's birth,
Am now grown strong upon necessity,
How forwards are we towards Windam castle.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Just half our way, but we have lost our friends,
Through the hot pursuit of our enemies.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We are not utterly devoid of friends,
Behold the young lord Willowby smiles on us,
And 'tis great help, to have a lord our friend.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Good heaven I pray once sort to happy end,
This dangerous pilgrimage, here undertook,
Sit on this bank a while, and rest our limbs,
Wearied with travail, as our minds with care.

div.stage: Enter Fox, Cluny, captain, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: You are a captain of the Palsgrave's band,
These are the other recreants, cease them both,
The hundred crowns proposed, are surely yours,
I know him valiant, and therefore I will climb
Up in this tree, to see, and not be seen,
Pray lends a hand, whilst you surprise them,
I will laughing stand.

sp.speaker: Fox,
sp.l: If I fit you not, ere you come down,
Say fox is a goose.

sp.speaker: 2. Captain
sp.l: Sir I attach you as an enemy
Unto the Palsgrave, in whose land you are,
You and you trull, obey it ye were best,
Or in resistance hazard both your lives.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Attach me sir, I know no reason why,
Nor to my knowledge am an enemy,
Unto the Palsgrave, or the meanest man
Within his confines, were are travellers,
And will immediately forsake the land.

sp.speaker: 2. Captain
sp.l: You are a lance knight, this your concubine.
And these your bastards, that by rapine live,
And thus disguised you come to undermine,
Our country's government, then yield yourselves.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Though misery hath stamped upon out brow
The mark of poverty, yet gentle stranger,
Do not so far forget all manliness,
To be a slanderer of the innocent.

sp.speaker: 2. Captain
sp.l: Term me a slanderer.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And a villain too, if thou maintain these defamations
Term me a thief, my wife a concubine,
My children base born; by a soldier's faith,
Wert thou the greatest spirit the palgrave hath,
I cannot brook this slavish insolence,
That I am angry, witness this reply,
I will defend mine honour though I die.

sp.speaker: 2. Captain
sp.l: Villains I charge you all environ him,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: So many to one silly passenger,
Then farewell woman weakness, welcome sword,
For once I'll play the man, to save my lord.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Why this is excellent, now I hope to live
To see them apprehended or else slain.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: These hopes I'll cross, by cutting down the branch
Whereon he builds this weak foundation.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: O I shall fall, help me good m. fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Ay, wherefore Cluny, to betray my lady?
So hateful Bonner, dived into the well,
So fall this damned parator to hell,
And now I'll help my mistress to my power,
Fox, come out a your hole, and take your cousin's part
Or I'll pull you out by the ears.
Help, help, our captains murdered, raise the town.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: The captain slain then fox 'tis best to fly,
And lest some sad mischance should second them,
I will convey these children to the woods,
That borders near at hand, o heaven I pray,
Make this disastrous time a happy day.
Cry within.help, help, our captains slain.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: I must down, bless my neck and care not.
Cry within.follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: O, my guts, a vengeance on this fox.
Cry within.this way, this way follow.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What cries are these, o hast thou slain the Cap.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: If he be slain, require not heaven his blood,
Of miserable Berty.
Within.help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A second volley of heart wounding words,
O fly my love, fly, fly, and save thy life,
before the town be raised, shift for yourself,
If you be taken, there's no way but death.
Within. Here, here, this way.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why stir you not, our foes are hard at hand.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I am so amazed I know not where to go,
I'll take this way.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Rather dear love take this.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: That way they come.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What shall we do,
Behold a ladder raised against this house,
In happy time, mount up and save your life,
I will defend the bottom with my sword,
And though heaven knows I am o'erlaid with woe,
I'll rather die than see your overthrow.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: But I shall leave thee to thine enemies.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Shift for your own life, take, no care for mine ▪
For heavens sake quickly, you delay the time.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Fear lend me wings, but o my griefs so great,
It ways me down, and I must needs retreat.
Cry within.come away, come away, ho! come away.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: They are at hand, o good my love mount up.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: See where they are that made the fray.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: You fellow, that run up the ladder,
Down, down, or I'll pull you down in a rope's name.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He is my husband, and a gentleman,
And I'll defend him from your tyranny.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: A woman fight.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Such are my fortunes now,
Therefore keep off, who ventures on this way,
Treadeth a path that leadeth to his death.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My friends what seek you, wherefore come? Armed you

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You have slain a captain of the palsgrave's band
wounded his soldiers, and besides we hear,
You are a lanceknight, this your concubine,
And come disguised to undermine the state,
In whose defence these men have armed themselves.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You seem a burgomaster, by your habit,
And they that misinformed you were too blame,
Know gentle sir, I am an Englishman,
And on some special business bound this way,
Towards Windam-castle, till we were disturbed,
By the oppression of the man that's slain.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: I wreak not friend of what estate you are,
Nor to what end you travail through these parts,
You have slain a map, and you must answer it,
According to the law of nations.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Down with him, he shall answer it with death.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Peace there, I charge you, in the prince's name.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It seems these men are thirsty for my blood,
And without law are set to take my life,
Than it were madness for a man to yield,
To abide a trial, and the judgement past:
Since I must die, I'll choose the death myself,
And that's to stand on a defensive guard,
Except you swear as you're a christian,
A magistrate, and one that will do right,
That I shall have due process of the law
And be defended from the multitude.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Do not, I pray, endanger so your life,
But trust unto the shelter you have got.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: A sorry fortress to defend his life.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: But will you take that oath.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: By heaven I do, and I will see it kept inviolate.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Then work the worst of fate, if right bear sway,
He cannot speed amiss that does no wrong,
O, innocence is bold, free, liberal,
Fearless of any danger, that may fall,
I 〈◊〉 me sir, a prisoner to the law,
justice is blind gaze not upon our persons,
Although our birth be ne'er so mean or base,
But fix the eye of judgement on our case.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: So, bind their hands, and lead them to the statehouse
They shall have justice done immediately,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O stay a while, I have lost my little babes,
What savage hand hath ta'en my children hence,
Whilst we were busied in this luckless brawl.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My children born away! o then I fear,
It is some treason to abridge our lives,
And that the captain, that did wrong us thus,
Did it to that intent.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis so, till now we ne'er were truly miserable,
Our other miseries were sunshine days,
Compared unto the greatness of this storm,
O suffer me good sir, to seek them out,
For without them, I am but half myself.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: A strict enquiry shall be made forthwith,
In every place that borders hereabouts ,
Grieve not too much, though such are poor men's treasure
What needy thief to steal them would take pleasure.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter burgomaster, Bertie, Duchess, followed by soldiers: other side, palsegrave, Erbaigh, and lords attendants.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave ▪
sp.l: Right welcome's Erbaigh, to the Poland King,
Nich'as van Houe, our worthy burgomaster,
What means this concourse of so many men,
And what are they that you lead bound with you.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Strangers, an please your excellence my lord,
That have committed murder in your realm,
Slain Wisendrop a captain of your band,
For which offence, our purpose is to lead them,
Unto the statehouse to receive their judgement.

sp.speaker: Erba.
sp.l: If I mistake not, I should know that face,
O 'tis the virtuous lady Katherine,
This m. Berty, her espoused husband,
And has your good stars in your pilgrimage,
Brought you amongst you friends?

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: The lady Katherine, what the suffolk's Duchess,
My quondam love, hailed through the streets with cords,
And for the murder of a man that lives,
O 'tis uncivil usage, my good lady,
You're villains all unto our sovereignty,
How dare you thus abuse her royal birth.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Pardon my lord, we did not know her state.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Her heavenly face, than which there's none more fair,
In England, or the world,
Might without other witness of her state,
Suffice to tell you, she was nobly born,
This is that Duchess, mirror of this age,
She whom the lordly Bishops of the realm,
Bonner, and Gardner, persecute so much,
Pardon me madam, that I have so long,
Suffered your excellence to stay in bonds.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This your acknowledgement, most mighty King,
Amazeth me, considering my distress,
For 'tis a common custom in the world,
To take no notice of the miserable.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: I stand amazed at this strange accident,
The circumstance whereof we'll hear elsewhere,
Mean time thrice welcome to the Polands King,
And much it grieves me that so great a Princess,
Should be so basely handled in my land.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.l: O help dear lord, and shield us from our foe ▪
We are pursued by Brunswick, and his captains,
Who seek our lives, we fly to your protection.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Whence are you friends.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The truest friends we have ▪
Of England mighty prince, I know them both,
The first is doctor sands, a worthy man,
The other Cranwell, and my secretary.

div.stage: Enter Brunswick, English captains, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: My lord of Erbaigh, and the King of Poland,
Shield not those traitors, both to heaven and men,
From the due punishment of their offence,
Behold an Englishman, and a commander of a good esteem ▪
Has his commission signed to apprehend,
This sands, and Cranwell, fled to you for help,
Then as you tender the privilege of princes,
Over their subjects ▪
Suffer this writ to have his current here,
As I have done through all my territories.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It ill beseems the noble Duke of Brunswick,
To be a persecutor of good men.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Or you good captain, agent in this cause.

sp.speaker: 1. Captain
sp.l: That's recreant Berty, and the suffolk's Duchess ▪
They likewise are included in this scroll.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: My lord of Poland, we demand them all,
Then yield them royal sir, unto our hands.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: First will I sacrifice ten thousand lives,
Ere suffer these religious souls to die,
My lord of Brunswick, you are over bold,
To make so rash an entrance in my land,
Without our special licence granted first.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: The league betwixt us warrants my approach.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: The league, for this time, is your privilege,
But as you dread the Palsgrave's puissance
And fear to violate our wrighten love,
Immediately untread your forward steps,
Forsake the soil where you have set your foot,
Or look to be withstood with fire and sword,
These lambs are fled into our folds for aid,
And we'll defend them, say what may be said.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: This disobedience draws upon your land,
Deserved malediction from the church.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: That we'll dispense withal, and to let you know,
How we do slight those stingless menaces,
Here I create this noble gentleman,
Earl of Crozam, an earldom under us,
Religious doctor sands, our chaplain,
And m. Cranwell our chief secretary,
So tell lord Bonner, Gardner, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Atkin.
sp.l: Health and long life unto the King of Poland,
Captain, from England's Queen, I thus salute you,
Here is a countermand for your commission,
By which you are enjoined to stay the search,
After the Suffolk Duchess, and her friends.

sp.speaker: 1 captain
sp.l: To stay the search? is our dread sovereign,
Altered in her religion, or is she dead:

sp.speaker: Atkin.
sp.l: She's dead good sir, Queen Mary is deceased,
And the most virtuous lady Elizabeth,
Invested in the regal dignity,
My sovereign hearing ▪ that the lady Katherine,
The Suffolk Duchess, her ally in blood,
Did live obscurely in these provinces,
In want, in misery, and great distress,
Sends to repeal both her, and all her friends,
if such a lady harbour in your land,
I do entreat her highness' proclamation,
May have his currant course through every town.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: In you dear sir the proclamation ends,
Here is the Duchess, here are all her friends.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I kindly thank you, for your worthy pains ▪
Hath the director of all humane lives,
Preserved my sovereign, that heroic maid,
From the intangling snares of blood and death,
And changed her prison, to a royal throne?
Here on this ground, where first I heard the news,
I render thanks unto the gracious heavens,
Thou that sendest balm of comfort to the wounded,
Joy to the bruised heart, oppressed for truth,
Lengthen her days as long as heaven hath stars,
Or this fair frame foundation for a world,
Or if it be thy gracious providence,
For to remove her to a happier place,
Let in her stead arise, and from her ashes come,
A phoenix may enlighten Christendom,
O, had I now my children lately lost,
I should survive as I had near been crossed.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: That comfort madam on my bent knee,
Your servant fox humbly presents your grace.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My Peregrine, my Susan, then for care
To make a mixture with this too much joy,
Or I shall surfeit with the rarety.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Justice my lord, justice, fox hath broke my neck

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: How comes it fox, that he exclaims on thee?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Marry an't please your majesty, 'twas thus,
This villainous rascal, followed to surprise my lady,
And being afraid to venture himself, set on one of 〈◊〉
Palsgrave's captains to do it, whilst he climbed
up into a tree and stood laughing, now sir, I cut the bow,
And he fell down, and if you have not broke your neck,
I would you had.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: If this be true, he has bought his pleasure dear,
Sirrah begone, this justice I allow,
For his derision then, deride him now.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: All things goes backward for our good,
Madam farewell, your punishment is past,
Now set your mind to punish us at last.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Revenge shall be a stranger in my heart,
The tortures I'll inflict upon my foes,
Is kindness, for unkindness, grace for death,
For what's prosperity but a puff of breath,
My lord of Brunswick, pray let us be friends.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Withal my heart, since every heart befriends you.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: It joys me that your sorrows here take end,
Wilt please you madam, here to stay with us
Or go for England, if you so resolve,
I'll see you furnished with a noble fleet.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: To England with full sails, blow gentle wind,
I long to see my sovereign noble maid,
Princes I humbly thank you for these honours,
Done to your handmaid, far unworthy them,
But time shall testify my thankfulness,
Be smooth rough sea, that I may pass a main,
To do my duty to my sovereign.

div.stage: Enter Bonner, with officers after him, two men, and a woman ▪

sp.l: Down with him, give us leave to be revenged on him.
For all the tyranny that he hath used

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What have I done, you should revile me thus?
What hast thou done to deserve our hate?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Defend me officers, shall I without law,
Be trod to death by the rude multitude.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: Keep off my masters,
'Tis her highness' pleasure,
he shall not be convicted but by law.
And whither goes he.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer
sp.l: To the Marshalsea.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will not leave him, till we see him in.

div.stage: Enter keeper, Grindall, Cox, and Scory.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: This is the prison, here the keeper comes,
And with him master Grindall, Scory, Cox,
Such reverent men as, Bonner, by your means,
These many years have suffered much distress ▪

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: But now they are delivered, and their place,
Bonner, you must another while supply,
So says the strict commission I have here.

sp.speaker: Grind.
sp.l: Trust me, I glory not to see his fall.

sp.speaker: Story.
sp.l: Believe me ▪ nor do I.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Though we know, had not our keeper been more kind to us
Than you were m. Bonner, we might here,
Have starved for want of meat, but heaven forgive you,
We do with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Scory.
sp.l: And we will labour too, so much as in us lies,
Unto the council, you may be favourably
Dealt withal, so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Farewell, this course inconstant fortune keeps,
While wan one laughs, another always weeps.

div.stage: Enter lord Hunsdon, admiral, and Clinton.

sp.l: Such measure as to others he hath met,
The same let him receive, good m. keeper.
Remember lollards-tower.
Let his best diet be but from the basket,
Nay, bread and water, is too good for him,
His fat Shrove-tuesday sides may well endure,
A hungry lent or two, and never hurt him ▪

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Here I deliver up my charge.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: And I receive him,
Come m. Bonner, you must go with me

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Stay I have bethought me, I'll recant.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: It cannot serve your turn.
Recant, he hath already twice or thrice done so.
Tut, he can turn with every weathercock,
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Come sir, will you go.

div.stage: Enter lord Hunsedon, admiral and Clinton, with staves, gentlemen atendants.

sp.speaker: Admiral
sp.l: Who wast that said the Duchess came through Southwark.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.l: 'Twas the lord Clinton.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: I left her grace now at s. George's church,
Accompanied with m. Richard Berty,
With doctor sands, Cranwell, and trusty fox,
And divers other gentlemen attendants.

sp.speaker: Admiral
sp.l: Here at the Marshalsea we'll stay her coming,
And hark, her trumpets sounds her near approach,
Lords, knights, and gentlemen, I pray you all
By that dear love you owe her majesty,
To be officious in the entertain,
Of this renowned lady Katherine.
sp.stage: Enter in state, the Duchess, Berty, sands, Cranwell, and Fox.
sp.l: Cry with in.heavens preserve your grace,
Your relief to poor prisoners.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What prison call you this?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: The kings-bench madam, where all these prisoners,
Are detained for debt.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: If they be able to make satisfaction, and will not,
They are worthy to lie there,
But if by cruelty of creditors,
'Tis Christian charity to succour such.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: I have heard that some lie there in policy,
And have engrossed into their greedy hands,
The goods of divers thrifty minded men,
And though well able, yet they will not pay.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Great pity that such men escape unpunished,
but are they in the number that do beg.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: No Madan, they are laid on beds of down,
Fare daintily, and never taste of want,
Except it be the want of liberty,
And that's no want, because they have large walks,
As yards, and gardens, and fair bowling-alleys,
With company at will to spend the time.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: To them we wish a better conscience,
But to the poor, and such as want indeed,
One of you give amongst them 40. Angels,
My troubles make me sensible of theirs:
Distress is sharply set, and bites too sore,
To be endured by such as are true poor,
So forwards gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Room for the lords.

sp.speaker: Admiral
sp.l: Thrice welcome is the noble suffolk's Duchess ▪
To us, and to her royal majesty,
In whose high favour, you are highly placed ▪

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: In sign whereof her princely majesty,
Restores you to your ancient signories,
Entitles you, as due to you by title,
Baroness of Willowby ▪ and Earsby,
Duchess dowager of Suffolk,
Her highness nearest and most dearest subject.

sp.speaker: Hunsd.
sp.l: Your goods, and lands extracted violently,
Her majesty restores to you again,
Here's the true inventory of them all,
As they were seized into the Bishop's hands.

sp.speaker: Admiral
sp.l: And that you may build on her princely love,
It is her pleasure, m. Richard Berty,
The husband of your troubles and your cares,
Should be chief secretary to the state,
Till higher titles do advance his worth.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: An honour my good lord admiral,
That I esteem, and yet desire it not,
Oh be it not offensive to her grace,
That I have leave to lead a private life,
after my painful travel in strange lands.

sp.speaker: Admiral
sp.l: Enjoy your mind's contentment with your mind.

sp.speaker: Hun.
sp.l: You, doctor sands, her highness, and the clergy,
Do consecrate Archbishop of York.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: An honour far exceeding my desert.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.l: Master Cranwell gentleman usher to her grace,
Her highness will retain in self same place,
To attend her majesty.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Withal my heart, I humbly tender a true subjects
Yet might it please her royal majesty,
Since I have served my lady in distress,
Endured so many troubles for her sake
That I may live, and die in serving her.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.l: A virtuous inclination, hold it still,
It will renown thee more than to be great.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My lord of Hunsdon, Clinton, Effingam,
I humbly thank her majesty, and you,
O may I live to express a loving heart,
By some good action pleasing to you all.

sp.speaker: Prisoner
sp.l: Madam be good unto a company of poor prisoners.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What other prison Cranwell call you this.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: This is the prison of the Marshalsea,
Chiefly pretended for her highness' household,
But there are divers other prisoners.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis charity to help distressed men,
Of what estate soe'er , 'cause they be men,
I leave their faults respect unto the law,
Give them as much as th'other prisons,
But what is he that with a downcast look,
Gives signs of discontentment.

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.l: Madam I am a prisoner here,
But joy to see your grace at liberty.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That face and voice, I oft have seen and heard,
Did not you sometime make abode in Lee.

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.l: Madam I did, and those that knew me called me goseling.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Then I am sure, you knew one mistress white,
This is the man that helped me to escape,
When we were near beset with Bonners trains.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: It is my kinsman madam, now I know him,
What cause hath brought thee to this hard distress.

sp.speaker: Gos
sp.l: The cause even now alleged.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Hath Bonner been so cruel to my friend,
Before mine eyelids wear the seal of sleep,
If heaven be pleased I will release thee goseling.
And pay thy charges to the utmost farthing,
O my dear friend, it never shall be said
I was ungrateful, where I was befriended,
And now his troubles make me call to mind,
The faithful dealing of my servant fox,
See lords, a man whom I dismissed my service,
More through self-will, than any just offence,
Yet hath he quit that disgrace so well,
That I admire the strangeness of his art,
For Bonner used him as a special means,
To seek my life, which oftentimes he saved,
Paying my great unkindness, with kind love,
Many such servants may this land afford,
That use their wits to such good purposes,
Here as a part of thy deserved reward,
I freely give thee a hundred pounds a year,
And when I die my land shall make it good.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: And when fox fails you, let him die in a ditch.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Gramercies gentle servant, now my lords,
Let's bend our pace towards famous London-bridge,
How pleasing is the prospect of the city,
Now I have been five years a stranger here,
Thorough the same to Whitehall to her grace,
That I may see my loving sovereign's face.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
